text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This transmits a revision to IRM 5.14.2, Installment Agreements, Partial Payment Installment Agreements and the Collection Statute Expiration Date (CSED). , .
MATERIAL CHANGES
IRM 5.14.2.1 has been updated to add the program scope and objectives to address management and internal controls.
and internal controls. (
) IRM
Added note regarding not using continuous wage levies in lieu of PPIAs. (
) IRM
) Added paragraph
to describe additional research required in certain (
) IRM
) Clariﬁed determination of payment amount for IBTF PPIA cases. (
) IRM

) replaced ICOMP references with IAT reference.
Various editorial changes and citation updates through out the section.
EFFECT ON OTHER DOCUMENTS

IRM 5.14.2, dated 12-18-2015, (effective 01-01-2016), is superseded. Incorporated interim memorandum SBSE-05-0418-0012, Interim Guidance for Revenue Officers regarding Changes Research Requirements for Certain Collection Cases, dated April 23, 2018.
SB/SE Collection Employees
Table of Contents
Partial Payment Installment Agreements and the Collection Statute Expiration Date (CSED) 5.14.2

Purpose. This IRM describes the establishment, approval and monitoring of installment agreements when the ﬁnancial analysis indicates the taxpayer will be unable to satisfy the tax liability within the Collection Statute Expiration Date (CSED). Procedures are also provided for situations in which it may be appro- priate to secure a Form
, Tax Collection Waiver, to extend the statutory period for collection in connection with granting a Partial Payment Installment Agreement (PPIA). Speciﬁcally, IRM

Purpose. This IRM describes the establishment, approval and monitoring of installment agreements when the ﬁnancial analysis indicates the taxpayer will be unable to satisfy the tax liability within the Collection Statute Expiration (CSED). Procedures are also provided for situations in which it may be appro- priate to secure a Form 900, Tax Collection Waiver, to extend the statutory period for collection in connection with granting a Partial Payment Installment Agreement (PPIA). Speciﬁcally, IRM 5.14.2:

Describes the required ﬁnancial analysis prior to establishing a Partial Payment Installment Agreement (PPIA) Describes the attributes of Asset and No Asset cases Describes situations in which it may be appropriate to extend the Collec- tion Stature Expiration Date (CSED) and the procedures for doing so Describes revenue officer responsibilities for working Campus referrals relative to
year reviews of PPIAs

Payment Installment Agreement (PPIA) b. Describes the attributes of Asset and No Asset cases c. Describes situations in which it may be appropriate to extend the tion Stature Expiration Date (CSED) and the procedures for doing so d. Describes revenue officer responsibilities for working Campus referrals relative to
year reviews of PPIAs (
) Audience. These procedures and guidance apply to IRS Field Collection revenue officers and group managers. (
) Policy Owner. The Director, Collection Policy is the owner of this IRM. (
) Program Owner. Collection Policy, Case Resolution Alternatives (CRA) is program owner of this IRM. (
) Primary Stakeholders • Field Collection • Independent Administrative Review • Insolvency • Appeals • Taxpayer Advocate Service • Centralized Case Processing/Field Office Resource Team (

) Program Goals. All taxpayers are expected to immediately full pay tax liabilities. When this is not possible, taxpayers may be allowed to pay liabilities over a prescribed period of time. By following the procedures in IRM, employees will be able to correctly establish a PPIA and extend the CSED when appropriate, and perform two-year reviews of PPIAs when required to do so. (

) All taxpayers are expected to immediately full pay delinquent tax liabilities. When this is not possible taxpayers may be allowed to pay their liabilities a prescribed period of time. Before a PPIA may be granted, equity in assets must be addressed and, if appropriate, be used to make payment. In some cases taxpayers will be required to use equity in assets to pay liabilities. However, complete utilization of equity is not always required as a condition a PPIA. (

) If full payment cannot be achieved by the Collection Statute Expiration Date (CSED), and taxpayers have some ability to pay, the Service can enter into Partial Payment Installment Agreements (PPIAs). The American Jobs Act of
amended IRC §
to provide this authority.

If full payment cannot be achieved by the Collection Statute Expiration Date (CSED), and taxpayers have some ability to pay, the Service can enter into Partial Payment Installment Agreements (PPIAs). The American Jobs Act of 2004 amended IRC § 6159 to provide this authority.
) IRC §
, Agreements for Payment of Tax Liability in Installments. (
) IRC §
(k), Levy and Distraint, No levy while certain offers pending or stallment agreements pending or in effect. (
) The Director, Collection Policy is the executive responsible for the policies procedures to be employed by collection personnel. (
) Field Collection group managers and territory managers are responsible for ensuring the guidance and procedures described in this IRM are complied with. (

) Program Reports: a. Monthly Installment Agreement Trend Report. Sourced from the Management tion Activity Report (CAR), Case Resolution Alternatives (CRA) Review office generates and reviews a monthly Installment Agreement trend report that captures data on the various types of installment and compares year to year data on installment agreement inventory levels, the number of installment agreements initiated, default rates, pay rates, and dollars collected (

) Program Effectiveness: a. CRA office will conduct ad hoc Installment Agreement program as necessary to verify compliance with IRM requirements, address TIGTA/GAO ﬁndings, and get behind any trends that appear. b. Case reviews are conducted by group managers to ensure with this IRM. c. Group managers are required to approve reinstated installment ments, as applicable. d. Operational reviews are conducted by the territory manager and area director annually to evaluate program delivery and conformance to ministrative and compliance requirements. (

) Independent Administrative Review (with few exceptions) is required of all rejected installment agreement proposals, and all modiﬁcation, rejection, Controls default and termination decisions are subject to appeal procedures. (
) The Integrated Collection System (ICS) ensures that required conditions met, that there are no unﬁled returns, and requires group manager

tion Activity Report (CAR), Case Resolution Alternatives (CRA) program office generates and reviews a monthly Installment Agreement trend report that captures data on the various types of installment agreements and compares year to year data on installment agreement inventory levels, the number of installment agreements initiated, default rates, full pay rates, and dollars collected

a. CRA office will conduct ad hoc Installment Agreement program reviews as necessary to verify compliance with IRM requirements, address TIGTA/GAO ﬁndings, and get behind any trends that appear. b. ) Independent Administrative Review (with few exceptions) is required of all rejected installment agreement proposals, and all modiﬁcation, rejection, default and termination decisions are subject to appeal procedures. (
) The Integrated Collection System (ICS) ensures that required conditions are met, that there are no unﬁled returns, and requires group manager approval for all PPIAs. (
) The Integrated Data Retrieval System (IDRS) programming requires that all open modules be included in an installment agreement for input to be success- ful. (

) Frequently used terms in this IRM along with their deﬁnition include: a. Delinquent Taxes: balance due, ACS balance due accounts and/or notice status accounts. b. Accrued Taxes: unassessed amounts due on returns, missed estimated tax payments or undeposited FTDs as of the date of contact.
The Integrated Data Retrieval System (IDRS) programming requires that all open modules be included in an installment agreement for input to be
Frequently used terms in this IRM along with their deﬁnition include:

Delinquent Taxes: balance due, ACS balance due accounts and/or notice status accounts. Accrued Taxes: unassessed amounts due on returns, missed estimated tax payments or undeposited FTDs as of the date of contact.
Accrued Taxes: unassessed amounts due on returns, missed estimated tax payments or undeposited FTDs as of the date of contact.
Partial Payment Installment Agreements and the Collection Statute Expiration Date (CSED) 5.14.2
Current Taxes: FTDs and ES amounts that become due after the date of contact.

) All taxpayers are expected to immediately full pay delinquent tax liabilities. When this is not possible, taxpayers may be allowed to pay their liabilities a prescribed period of time. If full payment cannot be achieved by the tion Statute Expiration Date (CSED), and taxpayers have some ability to the Service can enter into Partial Payment Installment Agreements (PPIAs). The American Jobs Creation Act of
amended IRC
to provide this authority. (

) Before a PPIA may be granted, equity in assets must be addressed and, if propriate, be used to make payment. In some cases, taxpayers will be to use equity in assets to pay liabilities. However, as discussed below, complete utilization of equity is not always required as a condition of a PPIA. Consider levy or seizure in accordance with IRM
, Seizure and Sale, IRM
, Notice of Levy if there is signiﬁcant equity in assets. If action is appropriate, a PPIA will not be granted. Follow rejection procedures IRM
, Securing Installment Agreements and IRM

) should not be used in of a PPIA if the taxpayer is current with ﬁling requirements and has the necessary ﬁnancial information to determine a payment amount unless the taxpayer refuses to sign the Form
D, Installment Agreement. Since CWLs are not installment agreements, taxpayers subject to them are not entitled to rights provided by section
and CWLs do not provide for a systemic redetermination of collectibility. (

A and/or Form
B must be completed to determine the taxpayer’s ability to pay (refer to IRM
, Allowable Expense Overview, to determine allowable expenses.) (

RTVUE b. TRDBV c. Current year tax return In addition, compare assets included on the ﬁnancial statement to the of information secured via these CCs/Returns. If the current year income decreased

% or more from the last ﬁled return income or assets are ﬁed that were not disclosed on the ﬁnancial statement, discuss and/or any discrepancy with the taxpayer and document the case history. ) Conditional expenses not determined to be necessary are not allowed for PPIAs. Only necessary expenses are permitted. When taxpayers need to adjust above allowable expenses, the minimum time necessary should be provided. See IRM
, Financial Analysis Handbook, for a discussion of necessary, conditional and other expenses and when exceptions may be ap- propriate.

D, Installment Agreement. Since CWLs are not installment agreements, taxpayers subject to them are not entitled to rights provided by section
and CWLs do not provide for a systemic redetermination of collectibility.

Continuous wage levies (CWL) (see IRM 5.11.5.6) should not be used in of a PPIA if the taxpayer is current with ﬁling requirements and has the necessary ﬁnancial information to determine a payment amount unless the taxpayer refuses to sign the Form 433D, Installment Agreement. Since CWLs are not installment agreements, taxpayers subject to them are not entitled to rights provided by section 7122 and CWLs do not provide for a systemic redetermination of collectibility.

) For in-business trust fund accounts, use the guidelines in IRM

), In- Business Trust Fund Installment Agreements Requiring Financial Analysis and Determining Ability to Pay, which state that at a minimum you should: a. Verify income and expenses. Use bank statements to verify both income and expenses; b. Request documentation if assets, liabilities, expenses or income appear questionable; c. Complete record checks to determine ownership and equity in real and personal property, including motor vehicles; d. If appropriate, request that taxpayers sell assets or borrow on equity in assets in order to make payment on the delinquent taxes; e. As noted in IRM

)(b), Summary of Agreement Criteria for Business Accounts , ensure that the taxpayer has the ability to pay current taxes as well as operating expenses and pay delinquent taxes. Note: ICS will not allow closing a case as an IBTF-IA PPIA (No Asset) with a back up Form
If the IA defaults, it must come back out for ﬁnancial review before it can be placed in CNC status. (

) Because the installment agreement will not fully satisfy the liability, the Trust Fund Recovery Penalty (TFRP) will usually be assessed. As the potential exists for the taxpayer to accrue additional liabilities, the RO needs to ensure the ASED is extended on accounts in which the trust fund balance is below amount in IRM
, Investigation and Recommendation of the TFRP, IRM
, Considerations for In-Business Installment Agreements, provides guidance that the RO can request a signature on Form

, Waiver Extending Statutory Period for Assessment of Trust Fund Recovery Penalty, from all potentially responsible persons to extend the statute to the expected end-date of the agreement plus one year. For PPIAs, this date will be the expected CSED expiration. (
) For out-of-business trust fund accounts, use the guidelines in IRM

, Trust Fund Recovery Penalties and Installment Agreements . Note: Because the underlying liability will not be fully paid, the TFRP will usually assessed. The only exception to this requirement is in circumstances in which there is no collection potential from the responsible officers. (

) The taxpayer must agree to pay the maximum monthly payment based upon the taxpayer’s ability to pay. When determining the maximum monthly both the collectability of the business and that of all individuals responsible for the TFRP should be determined. Consider having the responsible individual(s) that work for the liable entity reduce their salary by the amount of their ability to pay in order to increase the monthly payment of the business. Otherwise, place the responsible individual(s) in an active IA for their TFRP assessment. Taxpayers entering PPIAs who have defaulted an IA in the past

months will be required to make monthly payments via DDIA or PDIA unless they are unbanked and unemployed/self employed. If this is not possible, a PPIA may still be granted. The reason that a payroll deduction or direct debit agreement could not be secured must be documented in the case history. (
) Make a lien ﬁling determination or ensure that a Notice of Federal Tax Lien (NFTL) was previously ﬁled on all aggregate liabilities with a UBA greater Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.
R Any line marked with a is for Official Use

)(b), Summary of Agreement Criteria for Business Accounts , ensure that the taxpayer has the ability to pay current taxes as well as operating expenses and pay delinquent taxes.

) The taxpayer must agree to pay the maximum monthly payment based upon the taxpayer’s ability to pay. When determining the maximum monthly payment both the collectability of the business and that of all individuals responsible for the TFRP should be determined. Consider having the responsible individual(s) that work for the liable entity reduce their salary by the amount of their ability to pay in order to increase the monthly payment of the business. Otherwise, place the responsible individual(s) in an active IA for their TFRP assessment. Taxpayers entering PPIAs who have defaulted an IA in the past

months will be required to make monthly payments via DDIA or PDIA unless they are unbanked and unemployed/self employed. If this is not possible, a PPIA may still be granted. The reason that a payroll deduction or direct debit agreement could not be secured must be documented in the case history. (

Partial Payment Installment Agreements and the Collection Statute Expiration Date (CSED) 5.14.2
for Do-Not-File or Deferring the NFTL Filing. (
) The Campus will refer cases for revenue officer assignment in some See IRM
) No Asset/No Equity Cases: A PPIA may be granted if a taxpayer has no assets or equity in assets; or has liquidated available assets to make a tax payment. (

) Asset Cases: A PPIA may be granted if a taxpayer does not sell or cannot borrow against assets with equity because: a. the assets have minimal equity or the equity is insufficient to allow a creditor to loan funds; Example: some lenders require equity of greater than

% of value in order to grant the loan. b. the taxpayer is unable to utilize equity; Example: the property is held as a tenancy by the entirety in a state does not allow only one spouse to encumber such property, when only one spouse owes the tax and the non-liable declines to go along with the attempt to borrow, and the property does not appear to have been transferred into the tenancy to avoid the tax collection. c. the asset has some value but the taxpayer is unable to sell the asset because it is currently unmarketable; Example: the business taxpayer owns a vacant lot in a high-value but the lot cannot be sold until it meets certain regulations d. the asset is necessary to generate income for the PPIA and the ment will receive more from the future income generated by the asset than from the sale of the asset; e. it would impose an economic hardship on the taxpayer to sell borrow on equity in property, or use a liquid asset to pay the taxes. Economic hardship is deﬁned in
C.F.R.

as and taxpayer unable to pay his or her reasonable living expenses. Assets necessary for the production of income should also be included in the deﬁnition of economic hardship. Example: the taxpayer is on a ﬁxed income, such as social security, has the ability to make small monthly payments. The only asset is the taxpayer’s primary residence and there is the property. The revenue officer does a risk analysis and termines that seizing the property would cause an hardship because the taxpayer cannot ﬁnd suitable replace- ment housing and meet necessary living expenses if the property would be seized. f. the taxpayer’s loan payment would exceed the taxpayer’s disposable income and they would not qualify for a loan.
for Do-Not-File or Deferring the NFTL Filing.
No Asset/No Equity Cases: A PPIA may be granted if a taxpayer has no assets or equity in assets; or has liquidated available assets to make a
Asset Cases: A PPIA may be granted if a taxpayer does not sell or cannot borrow against assets with equity because:
the property is held as a tenancy by the entirety in a state that does not allow only one spouse to encumber such property, when only one spouse owes the tax and the non
liable spouse declines to go along with the attempt to borrow, and the property does not appear to have been transferred into the tenancy to avoid the tax collection.

the asset is necessary to generate income for the PPIA and the govern- ment will receive more from the future income generated by the asset than from the sale of the asset; it would impose an economic hardship on the taxpayer to sell property, borrow on equity in property, or use a liquid asset to pay the taxes. Economic hardship is deﬁned in
C.F.R.
as and individual taxpayer unable to pay his or her reasonable living expenses. Assets necessary for the production of income should also be included in the deﬁnition of economic hardship.

Example: the taxpayer is on a ﬁxed income, such as social security, and has the ability to make small monthly payments. The only asset is the taxpayer’s primary residence and there is equity in the property. The revenue officer does a risk analysis and de
termines that seizing the property would cause an economic hardship because the taxpayer cannot ﬁnd suitable replace
ment housing and meet necessary living expenses if the property would be seized.
the taxpayer’s loan payment would exceed the taxpayer’s disposable income and they would not qualify for a loan.
economic hardship. Note: See IRM
, Other Expenses for additional information regarding necessary expenses. (

) When ﬁnancial analysis indicates that borrowing against or selling property should be attempted, the taxpayer will normally be required to make a good faith attempt to utilize equity before the Service will approve a PPIA. This includes applying normal business standards when applying for loans using equity as collateral. Taxpayers will also be required to submit copies of all documents that are used in the loan application process. (

) If the taxpayer does not comply with the requirement of making a good faith attempt to use equity in assets or is not willing to make monthly payments sistent with ability to pay, the taxpayer will be considered a “won’t pay” and seizure/levy action may be appropriate. If enforcement action is appropriate, PPIA will not be granted. If the taxpayer is in pending IA status, follow procedures in sections IRM
, Identifying Pending, Approved and Rejected Installment Agreement Proposals on IDRS, and IRM
, Monitoring. The case history should be documented with a statement as to why the PPIA was not granted. (
) If the taxpayer is unable to secure a loan or liquidate an asset following a faith attempt to do so, the revenue officer will need to make a seizure/levy termination (see IRM
, Actions Required Prior to Seizure by IRC

) If it has been determined that enforcement action is not appropriate, a PPIA can be granted. The case history should be documented as follows: (or levy) of (name of asset) has been considered, but it is not the resolution because (provide reason)”. (

) Consider securing a waiver with a PPIA where there is an asset that will into the possession of a taxpayer after the CSED and liquidation of that offers the best case resolution (in lieu of liquidating existing assets to pay the liability). Note: Do not include any Affordable Care Act individual shared responsibility payment liabilities (MFT
and Mirrored MFT
) on the waiver.
Note: See IRM 5.15.1.11, Other Expenses for additional information regarding necessary expenses.

When ﬁnancial analysis indicates that borrowing against or selling property should be attempted, the taxpayer will normally be required to make a faith attempt to utilize equity before the Service will approve a PPIA. This includes applying normal business standards when applying for loans using equity as collateral. Taxpayers will also be required to submit copies of all documents that are used in the loan application process. If the taxpayer does not comply with the requirement of making a good

faith attempt to utilize equity before the Service will approve a PPIA. This includes applying normal business standards when applying for loans using equity as collateral. Taxpayers will also be required to submit copies of all documents that are used in the loan application process. If the taxpayer does not comply with the requirement of making a good faith attempt to use equity in assets or is not willing to make monthly payments sistent with ability to pay, the taxpayer will be considered a “won’t pay” and seizure/levy action may be appropriate. If enforcement action is appropriate, a PPIA will not be granted. If the taxpayer is in pending IA status, follow rejection procedures in sections IRM
, Identifying Pending, Approved and Rejected Installment Agreement Proposals on IDRS, and IRM
, IDRS Monitoring. The case history should be documented with a statement as to why the PPIA was not granted.
Note: Do not include any Affordable Care Act individual shared responsibility payment liabilities (MFT 35 and Mirrored MFT 65) on the waiver.

The taxpayer owes individual income tax and is the beneﬁciary of a trust. The taxpayer will receive a monthly distribution from the trust that would be used to fund the PPIA. The taxpayer will not be entitled to the principal of the trust for two more years. The CSED will expire in one year. The only other asset is the taxpayer’s primary residence. The equity in the property is less than the net value of the trust but is available for immediate collection action. The taxpayer has been unable to secure a loan against the equity of the property due to numerous factors such as limited income and poor credit. The risk analysis was completed by the revenue officer and the taxpayer offered to extend the statute and to liquidate the trust in two years. The waiver was secured for two additional years.
Payment Installment Agreements and the Collection Expiration Date (CSED) 5.14.2
Example: A corporate taxpayer cannot pay its payroll tax liability within the CSED. It can make partial payments for the remaining CSED period. The corpo-
A corporate taxpayer cannot pay its payroll tax liability within the CSED. It can make partial payments for the remaining CSED period. The corpo

ration is current with its federal tax deposits. The corporation has an interest in undeveloped real estate which is under development and will be completed in two years. Once the land is developed it will increase signiﬁcantly in value and will be immediately sold. The CSED will expire in one year. Seizing and selling the assets of the business which would include the vacant land and construction equipment would not signiﬁ

cantly reduce the liability and would impact the business’s ability to complete the development of the property. The corporate officers offer to extend the statute to provide the opportunity to complete the develop
ment and pay the taxes along with other business debts. The trust fund recovery penalty will be addressed per IRM procedures.

It can make partial payments for the remaining CSED period. The ration is current with its federal tax deposits. The corporation has an interest in undeveloped real estate which is under development and will be completed in two years. Once the land is developed it will increase signiﬁcantly in value and will be immediately sold. The CSED will expire in one year. Seizing and selling the assets of the business which would include the vacant land and construction equipment would not signiﬁ- cantly reduce the liability and would impact the business’s ability to complete the development of the property. The corporate officers offer extend the statute to provide the opportunity to complete the develop- ment and pay the taxes along with other business debts. The trust fund recovery penalty will be addressed per IRM procedures.

A waiver is no longer required to be secured when the taxpayer’s only ability to satisfy the tax liability after the CSED expiration is through a continuation of the installment agreement and there is no signiﬁcant change in ability to pay as identiﬁed through the two year ﬁnancial review process.
The taxpayer cannot pay the liability within the CSED but can make monthly payments. The statute will expire in twelve months. The taxpayer has no distrainable assets. The taxpayer owes $
and can pay $
per month. Secure a PPIA for twelve months and no waiver is required. The statute would be allowed to expire.

Example: The individual taxpayer cannot pay the liability within the CSED but can make monthly payments. The statute will expire in three years. The taxpayer owns real property with minimal equity and they cannot borrow against the equity. The taxpayer owes $
and can pay $

per month. Secure a PPIA for three years and no waiver is required. There will be a two year ﬁnancial review conducted. If there is no signiﬁcant change in ability to pay, the payment amount will remain unchanged the statute expires. A waiver could not be secured during the two year ﬁnancial review process unless the taxpayer’s ﬁnancial condition has improved, the agreement is terminated, and a new one is granted. ) The American Jobs Creation Act of

to provide the authority for the Service to enter into partial payment installment agreements (i.e., installment agreements that do not provide for full payment of the liabili- ties). If full payment cannot be achieved by the Collection Statute Expiration Date (CSED), and taxpayers have some ability to pay, the Service can grant Partial Payment Installment Agreements (PPIAs). IRC

)(A) provides that statutory periods for collection may be extended in connection with granting installment agreements. CSED extensions are permitted only in junction with PPIAs and only in certain situations . CSED extensions are limited to ﬁve years beyond the original CSED (and where applicable, any previous extensions due to statutory suspension of the CSED) for each tax account plus up to one year (see IRM
). Group managers must approve CSED extensions.. If the taxpayer enters into more than one PPIA, the CSED may be extended more than once for each balance due account. (

) Be aware of the CSED when granting installment agreements. Use the IAT Compliance Suite Payment Calculator to verify that the agreement will fully all liabilities for which the taxpayer is liable prior to the CSED and include a copy with the case ﬁle. If the projected date for full payment is prior to the CSED, the agreement may be approved. If the projected date for full is not prior to the CSED, a Partial Payment Installment Agreement may be considered (see IRM

) Prior suspensions of CSEDs due to offers in compromise or legal proceedings do not: • bar extensions of CSEDs with PPIAs, • change the length of extensions beyond the limits provided in this section.
Therefore, CSED suspensions may result in longer periods for collection than provided otherwise by this section (as illustrated in Exhibit 5.14.2–1). For example, the CSED is suspended:

while the IRS and the Office of Appeals consider a request for an ment agreement or an offer in compromise from the date the taxpayer requests a CDP hearing until Appeals issues a CDP Notice of Determination or, if the taxpayer seeks review in the Tax Court, until the Tax Court’s decision becomes ﬁnal, including appeals to a United States Court of Appeals from the date the taxpayer requests innocent spouse relief until a ﬁnal Notice of Determination is issued or, if the taxpayer seeks review in the Tax Court, the date the Tax Court decision becomes ﬁnal and for
days thereafter. If, however, the taxpayer appeals the Tax Court’s
decision to a United States Court of Appeals, the collection period will begin to run
days after the ﬁling of the appeal unless a bond is posted with the appeal for tax periods included in a bankruptcy while the automatic stay is in effect, plus an additional six months
The IRS is unable to collect for
months while the taxpayer is in bank- ruptcy and the automatic stay is in effect. Thus, the period for collection is suspended for
months under IRC sec.

(h). After adjusting the CSED to reﬂect the bankruptcy, the CSED may still be extended by agreement for a period of ﬁve years if there is a partial payment install- ment agreement and the other criteria for securing a Form
, Tax Collection Waiver, have been met.
See IRC 6503 for other examples of situations that suspend the CSED.

All tax modules for which the taxpayer is liable must be included in extension calculations using the IAT Compliance Suite Payment Calculator. Extensions will be calculated from the latest CSED balance due account modules, but the waiver extends the CSED for all assessments on the tax module. On accounts with multiple CSED dates determine if the earliest CSED is still valid. To verify the CSED consider using the CCALC tool found at http://mysbse.web.irs.gov/ collection/toolsprocess/csedcalculator/default.aspx. If a TC
with a

or dol- lar amount appears on the module the CSED has expired for the associated CSED. Do not include this amount in your calculations. If there is more than one assessment on tax modules, and part of the balance due is from the ear- lier assessment(s), list these assessment dates on the waiver, along with the latest assessment date.

) Using IAT Compliance Suite Payment Calculator , two methods – described (a) and (b) immediately below – may be used for determining the length of CSED extensions. For both methods: • Include all tax modules in the computation; • Compute the extension separately for each module; • Begin the computation using the module with the earliest CSED; and, • Add additional modules to the computation until all are included.
This may result in extensions longer than six years for parts of some due tax modules.

Method (A) provides for computation of separate CSEDs for each module. Method (B) provides for extending CSEDs to one date for all modules.

Method (A) – Extend CSEDs on all modules to separate dates (for each module) up to one year past the latest CSED on the module, ensuring CSED extension is longer than ﬁve years (plus one year as speciﬁed in IRM
)). Method (B): Extend CSEDs to the same date for all modules, ensuring no CSED extension is longer than ﬁve years, plus one year.

For CSED extensions/waivers obtained prior to January 1, 2000 and not secured with installment agreements, the statutory period for collection
Payment Installment Agreements and the Collection Expiration Date (CSED) 5.14.2
expire on December 31, 2002, or at the end of the original ten year statutory period for collection if after December 31, 2002. (See IRC 6502(a)(2) and IRC 3461(c)(2) of RRA ‘98).
